WRITING.TEXT: Well, considering how long it's taking me to get my PhD, you may be wrong about that horse.

Of course I have bills and pay a large corporation for the car that I drive. But I did not go to school to "literally just . . . to learn how to work for other people." I went to school so that I could work for myself, which is what I do, and I do it quite well, actually. I could not have done that without university.
If you're truly unable to fathom "why anyone goes to college" then this is probably not a debate I'm ever going to win . . .
Um, no. I was having to work for other people until I got an education, where I learned how to work for myself.
Indeed.
A chaotic evil goat druid!
I'm sure my character could use a little goat wisdom every now and then.

So you were binding books, like, as part of your job?

WRITING.TITLE: What do you think about spiral-bound RPG books?
WRITING.TEXT: We all own many lavish hardcover rule books, and they're lovely. But I recently took my Shadowrun main rule book to the office supply store and had them chop off the spine and replace it with what they call a "comb binding." The book lays perfectly flat on the table, and I like it a lot! Maybe it doesn't look as nice when vertical on a bookshelf, as the title is no longer on the spine, but so far I have no regrets.

Thanks for your reply! I think editorial choices make more of a difference than a director's choices of how to shoot to scene, but that's just my personal and somewhat uninformed opinion. Character development is another story entirely. Everything in TFA just seems really straightforward and basic. I agree that the opening minutes of R1 are all over the place. But most of the scenes are composed with more maturity.
One bit of camerawork in TFA that I DO love is Finn's long run through the battle outside of Maz's cantina. That's a great shot. Otherwise it just feels clunky to me.
But this is not meant as a critique of TFA specifically. I'm looking more at Abrams's filmography and wondering why it doesn't match up to his popularity. He's the go-to guy for reboots and sequels . . . and that's about it.

Thanks for the reply! Could you elaborate on how Abrams is improving as a visual director? I've been analyzing THE FORCE AWAKENS and trying to produce a compare/contrast with ROGUE ONE--which seems to be a much better film, at least from a technical standpoint (cinematography, editing, directing). Thanks again!

WRITING.TITLE: I would like to make some criticisms of J.J. Abrams in this subreddit, but I don't like conflict. : )
WRITING.TEXT:
I need opinions outside of my film class. When I look at the feature films that Abrams has directed, everything is a reboot or a sequel or--in the case of SUPER 8--intentionally derivative. Further, his directing style seems pretty basic compared to some of the example scenes from other directors that we watch in class (such as David Fincher). So Abrams has directed nothing original, and there's nothing innovative about his directorial choices, so why is he so popular?
I really hesitate to ask, because I'm not trolling and am looking for some serious discussion points for our next class meeting.

WRITING.TITLE: Frequent Insider updates are cool, but eventually the hardware will simply be too old.
WRITING.TEXT: My 950 is a year old and still performs well, but just like my five-year-old laptop is now laggy, my phone will one day need a refresh. So surely Something New is on the distant horizon . . . ?
Grow up.

"Ferrari's involvement is integral to the sustainability and success of the F1 business model. They receive payment based on their value to that model."
Yes, we all understand this. I was asking about a comparison of numbers, which other Redditors graciously provided.
This is the answer I was seeking. Thanks for explaining!
Actually that's not the "simple answer." In fact, it doesn't answer my question at all.
Okay, but the question remains. I need a ELI5 for the F1 payout structure.

WRITING.TITLE: GPUpdate quotes South East Labour MEP Anneliese Dodds as saying, "Smaller teams are unfairly punished by an uncompetitive allocation of prize money that will always give the biggest teams more money, even if they finish last in every race." Is that true?
WRITING.TEXT:
Lets say that both Ferrari cars retired in every race of the season and they scored 0 points. At seasons end, would Ferrari still receive a larger payout than Sauber? What if the Sauber cars finished 1-2 in every race and they won both championships? Would Ferrari STILL receive more money?
Sorry for the somewhat n00b question, but the F1 payout process has always baffled me.

WRITING.TITLE: It seems the damage from my frag mines has been greatly reduced. I deal those mines to my enemies like I'm dealing cards at a poker table, so this makes me sad.
WRITING.TEXT: I have two ranks in the Demolitions Expert perk, and for quite some time my frag mines and grenades have been doing an extra 50% damage. Now the mines have returned to base damage. Grenades haven't been reduced. I searched for known bugs on the issue but came up empty.
